greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of distinct Gaussian primes in the factorization of n.
comment: As shown in the formula, a(n) depends on the number of distinct primes of the forms 4*k+1 (A005089) and 4*k-1 (A005091) and whether n is divisible by 2 (A059841).
Note that associated divisors are counted only once. - _Jianing Song_, Aug 30 2018
link: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
formula: Additive with a(p^e) = 2 if p = 1 (mod 4), 1 otherwise. - _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Oct 18 2006
example: a(1006655265000) = a(2^3*3^2*5^4*7^5*11^3) = 1 + 2*1 + 3 = 6 because n is divisible by 2, has 1 prime factor of the form 4*k+1 and 3 primes of the form 4*k+3. Over the Gaussian integers, 1006655265000 is factored as i*(1 + i)^6*(2 + i)^4*(2 - i)^4*3^2*7^5*11^3, the 6 distinct Gaussian factors are 1 + i, 2 + i, 2 - i, 3, 7 and 11.
mathematica: Join[{0}, Table[f=FactorInteger[n, GaussianIntegers->True]; cnt=Length[f]; If[MemberQ[{-1, I, -I}, f[[1, 1]]], cnt-- ]; cnt, {n, 2, 100}]]
program: (PARI) a(n)=my(f=factor(n)[,1]); sum(i=1,#f,if(f[i]%4==1,2,1)) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Sep 14 2015
xref: Cf. A005089, A005091, A059841, A078458 (number of Gaussian primes, with multiplicity).
results.author: _T. D. Noe_, Jul 14 2003
